SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Leonato Gouernour of Meſſina, Innogen his wife, He-ro his daughter, and Beatrice his Neece, with a meſſenger

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: I learne in this Letter, that Don Peter of Arra-gon, comes this night to Meſſina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: He is very neere by this: he was not three Leagues off when I left him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: How many Gentlemen haue you lost in this action?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But few of any ſort, and none of name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: A victorie is twice it ſelfe, when the atchieuer brings home full numbers: I finde heere, that Don Pe-ter hath bestowed much honor on a yong Florentine, cal-led Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Much deseru’d on his part, and equally remem-bred by Don Pedro, he hath borne himselfe beyond the promise of his age, doing in the figure of a Lambe, the feats of a Lion, he hath indeede better bettred expecta-tion, then you must expect of me to tell you how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath an Vnckle heere in Meſſina, wil be very much glad of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue alreadie deliuered him letters, and there appeares much ioy in him, euen ſo much, that ioy could not ſhew it ſelfe modest enough, without a badg of bit-terneſſe. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Did he breake out into teares?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: In great measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: A kinde ouerflow of kindneſſe, there are no fa-ces truer, then those that are ſo wash’d, how much bet-ter is it to weepe at ioy, then to ioy at weeping?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto return’d from the warres, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I know none of that name, Lady, there was none ſuch in the armie of any ſort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he that you aske for Neece?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: My cousin meanes Signior Benedick of Padua

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O he's return’d, and as pleasant as euer he was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſet vp his bils here in Meſſina, & challeng’d Cupid at the Flight: and my Vnckles foole reading the Challenge, ſubscrib’d for Cupid, and challeng’d him at the Burbolt. I pray you, how many hath hee kil’d and eaten in these warres? But how many hath he kil’d? for indeed, I promis’d to eate all of his killing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith Neece, you taxe Signior Benedicke too much, but hee'l be meete with you, I doubt it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath done good ſeruice Lady in these wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You had musty victuall, and he hath holpe to ease it: he's a very valiant Trencher-man, hee hath an excellent ſtomacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And a good ſouldier too Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: And a good ſouldier to a Lady. But what is he to a Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: A Lord to a Lord, a man to a man, ſtuft with all honourable vertues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo indeed, he is no leſſe then a ſtuft man: but for the ſtuffing well, we are all mortall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: You must not (sir) mistake my Neece, there is a kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick, & her: they neuer meet, but there's a ſkirmish of wit between them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, he gets nothing by that. In our last con-flict, foure of his fiue wits went halting off, and now is the whole man gouern’d with one: ſo that if hee haue wit enough to keepe himselfe warme, let him beare it for a difference betweene himselfe and his horse: For it is all the wealth that he hath left, to be knowne a reaso-nable creature. Who is his companion now? He hath euery month a new ſworne brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Very easily poſſible: he weares his faith but as the fashion of his hat, it euer changes with y next block.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee (Lady) the Gentleman is not in your bookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: No, and he were, I would burne my ſtudy. But I pray you, who is his companion? Is there no young ſquarer now, that will make a voyage with him to the diuell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: He is mo’t in the company of the right noble
Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, he will hang vpon him like a disease: he is ſooner caught then the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God helpe the noble Claudio, if hee haue caught the Benedict, it will cost him a thousand pound ere he be cur’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I will hold friends with you Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: Do good friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: You'l ne're run mad Neece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not till a hot Ianuary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Don Pedro is approach’d.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter don Pedro, Claudio, Benedicke, Balthasar, and Iohn the bastard

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: the fashion of the world is to auoid cost, and you encounter it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer came trouble to my house in the likenes of your Grace: for trouble being gone, comfort ſhould remaine: but when you depart from me, ſorrow abides, and happineſſe takes his leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: You embrace your charge too willingly: I thinke this is your daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Her mother hath many times told me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Were you in doubt that you askt her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Benedicke, no, for then were you a childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue it full Benedicke, we may gheſſe by this, what you are, being a man, truely the Lady fathers her ſelfe: be happie Lady, for you are like an honorable father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: If Signior Leonato be her father, ſhe would not haue his head on her ſhoulders for al Meſſina, as like him as ſhe is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder that you will ſtill be talking, ſignior
Benedicke, no body markes you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: What my deere Ladie Disdaine! are you yet liuing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it poſſible Disdaine ſhould die, while ſhee hath ſuch meete foode to feede it, as Signior Benedicke? Curtesie it ſelfe must conuert to Disdaine, if you come in her presence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Then is curtesie a turne-coate, but it is cer-taine I am loued of all Ladies, onely you excepted: and I would I could finde in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truely I loue none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: A deere happineſſe to women, they would else haue beene troubled with a pernitious Suter, I thanke God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that, I had rather heare my Dog barke at a Crow, than a man ſweare he loues me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: God keepe your Ladiship ſtill in that minde, ſo ſome Gentleman or other ſhall ſcape a predestinate ſcratcht face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Scratching could not make it worse, and 'twere ſuch a face as yours were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you are a rare Parrat teacher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: A bird of my tongue, is better than a beast of your.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: I would my horse had the ſpeed of your tongue, and ſo good a continuer, but keepe your way a Gods name, I haue done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You alwaies end with a Iades tricke, I know you of old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the ſumme of all: Leonato, ſignior Clau-dio, and ſignior Benedicke; my deere friend Leonato, hath inuited you all, I tell him we ſhall ſtay here, at the least a moneth, and he heartily praies ſome occasion may de-taine vs longer: I dare ſweare hee is no hypocrite, but praies from his heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſweare, my Lord, you ſhall not be for-sworne, let mee bid you welcome, my Lord, being re-conciled to the Prince your brother: I owe you all duetie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you, I am not of many words, but I thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Please it your grace leade on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Your hand Leonato, we will goe together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Benedicke, didst thou note the daughter of ſig-nior
Leonato?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I noted her not, but I lookt on her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe not a modest yong Ladie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you question me as an honeſt man ſhould doe, for my ſimple true iudgement? or would you haue me ſpeake after my custome, as being a profeſſed tyrant to their ſexe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I pray thee ſpeake in ſober iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Why yfaith me thinks ſhee's too low for a hie praise, too browne for a faire praise, and too little for a great praise, onely this commendation I can affoord her, that were ſhee other then ſhe is, ſhe were vnhandsome, and being no other, but as ſhe is, I doe not like her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou think'st I am in ſport, I pray thee tell me truely how thou lik'st her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you buie her, that you enquier after her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Can the world buie ſuch a iewell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and a case to put it into, but ſpeake you this with a ſad brow? Or doe you play the flowting iacke, to tell vs Cupid is a good Hare-finder, and Vulcan a rare Carpenter: Come, in what key ſhall a man take you to goe in the ſong?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: In mine eie, ſhe is the ſweetest Ladie that euer
I lookt on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I can ſee yet without ſpectacles, and I ſee no ſuch matter: there's her cosin, and ſhe were not poſſest with a furie, exceedes her as much in beautie, as the first of Maie doth the last of December: but I hope you haue no intent to turne husband, haue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I would ſcarce trust my ſelfe, though I had ſworne the contrarie, if Hero would be my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ist come to this? in faith hath not the world one man but he will weare his cap with ſuspition? ſhall I ne-uer ſee a batcheller of three ſcore againe? goe to yfaith, and thou wilt needes thrust thy necke into a yoke, weare the print of it, and ſigh away ſundaies: looke, don Pedro is returned to ſeeke you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter don Pedro, Iohn the bastard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſecret hath held you here, that you fol-lowed not to Leonatœs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: I would your Grace would constraine mee to tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: I charge thee on thy allegeance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: You heare, Count Claudio, I can be ſecret as a dumbe man, I would haue you thinke ſo (but on my al-legiance, marke you this, on my allegiance) hee is in loue, With who? now that is your Graces part: marke how ſhort his answere is, with Hero, Leonatœs ſhort daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If this were ſo, ſo were it vttred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Like the old tale, my Lord, it is not ſo, nor 'twas not ſo: but indeede, God forbid it ſhould be ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If my paſſion change not ſhortly, God forbid it ſhould be otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, if you loue her, for the Ladie is verie well worthie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſpeake this to fetch me in, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth I ſpeake my thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And in faith, my Lord, I ſpoke mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: And by my two faiths and troths, my Lord, I ſpeake mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: That I loue her, I feele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhe is worthie, I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: That I neither feele how ſhee ſhould be lo-ued, nor know how ſhee ſhould be worthie, is the opinion that fire cannot melt out of me, I will die in it at the ſtake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wast euer an obstinate heretique in the de-spight of Beautie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And neuer could maintaine his part, but in the force of his will

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: That a woman conceiued me, I thanke her: that ſhe brought mee vp, I likewise giue her mo’t humble thankes: but that I will haue a rechate winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an inuisible baldricke, all women ſhall pardon me: because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will doe my ſelfe the right to trust none: and the fine is, (for the which I may goe the finer) I will liue a Batchellor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall ſee thee ere I die, looke pale with loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: With anger, with ſickneſſe, or with hunger, my Lord, not with loue: proue that euer I loose more blood with loue, then I will get againe with drinking, picke out mine eyes with a Ballet-makers penne, and hang me vp at the doore of a brothel-house for the ſigne of blinde Cupid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, if euer thou doost fall from this faith, thou wilt proue a notable argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a Cat, & ſhoot at me, and he that hit's me, let him be clapt on the ſhoul-der, and cal’d Adam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, as time ſhall trie: In time the ſauage
Bull doth beare the yoake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſauage bull may, but if euer the ſensible Benedicke beare it, plucke off the bulles hornes, and ſet them in my forehead, and let me be vildely painted, and in ſuch great Letters as they write, heere is good horse to hire: let them ſignifie vnder my ſigne, here you may ſee Benedicke the married man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If this ſhould euer happen, thou wouldst bee horne mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if Cupid haue not ſpent all his Quiuer in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this ſhortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I looke for an earthquake too then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you will temporize with the houres, in the meane time, good Signior Benedicke, repaire to Leo-natœs, commend me to him, and tell him I will not faile him at ſupper, for indeede he hath made great prepara-tion. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue almost matter enough in me for ſuch an
Embaſſage, and ſo I commit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: To the tuition of God. From my house, if I had it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſixt of Iuly. Your louing friend, Benedick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay mocke not, mocke not; the body of your discourse is ſometime guarded with fragments, and the guardes are but ſlightly basted on neither, ere you flout old ends any further, examine your conscience, and ſo I leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: My Liege, your Highneſſe now may doe mee good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: My loue is thine to teach, teach it but how,
And thou ſhalt ſee how apt it is to learne
Any hard Leſſon that may do thee good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath Leonato any ſonne my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: No childe but Hero, ſhe's his onely heire.
Dost thou affect her Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I look’d vpon her with a ſouldiers eie,
That lik’d, but had a rougher taske in hand,
Than to driue liking to the name of loue:
But now I am return’d, and that warre-thoughts
Haue left their places vacant: in their roomes,
Come thronging ſoft and delicate desires,
All prompting mee how faire yong Hero is,
Saying I lik’d her ere I went to warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wilt be like a louer presently,
And tire the hearer with a booke of words:
If thou dost loue faire Hero, cherish it,
And I will breake with her: wast not to this end,
That thou beganst to twist ſo fine a ſtory?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſweetly doe you minister to loue,
That know loues griefe by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too ſodaine ſeeme,
I would haue ſalu’d it with a longer treatise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What need y bridge much broder then the flood?
The fairest graunt is the neceſſitie:
Looke what will ſerue, is fit: ‘tis once, thou louest,
And I will fit thee with the remedie,
I know we ſhall haue reuelling to night,
I will aſſume thy part in ſome disguise,
And tell faire Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosome Ile vnclaspe my heart,
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And ſtrong incounter of my amorous tale:
Then after, to her father will I breake,
And the conclusion is, ſhee ſhall be thine,
In practise let vs put it presently.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Leonato and an old man, brother to Leonato.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: How now brother, where is my cosen your ſon: hath he prouided this musicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: He is very busie about it, but brother, I can tell you newes that you yet dreamt not of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.
SPEECH.LINE: Are they good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: As the euents ſtamps them, but they haue a good couer: they ſhew well outward, the Prince and Count Claudio walking in a thick pleached alley in my orchard, were thus ouer-heard by a man of mine: the Prince dis-couered to Claudio that hee loued my niece your daugh-ter, and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance, and if hee found her accordant, hee meant to take the present time by the top, and instantly breake with you of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: A good ſharpe fellow, I will ſend for him, and question him your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no; wee will hold it as a dreame, till it ap-peare it ſelfe: but I will acquaint my daughter withall, that ſhe may be the better prepared for an anſwer, if per-aduenture this bee true: goe you and tell her of it: coo-sins, you know what you haue to doe, O I crie you mer-cie friend, goe you with mee and I will vse your ſkill, good cosin haue a care this busie time. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Sir Iohn the Bastard, and Conrade his companion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: What the good yeere my Lord, why are you thus out of measure ſad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds, therefore the ſadneſſe is without limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould heare reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: And when I haue heard it, what bleſſing brin-geth it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: If not a present remedy, yet a patient ſufferance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder that thou (being as thou ſaist thou art, borne vnder Saturne) goest about to apply a morall me-dicine, to a mortifying mischiefe: I cannot hide what I am: I must bee ſad when I haue cause, and ſmile at no mans iests, eat when I haue ſtomacke, and wait for no mans leisure: ſleepe when I am drowsie, and tend on no mans busineſſe, laugh when I am merry, and claw no man in his humor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, but you must not make the ful ſhow of this, till you may doe it without controllment, you haue of late ſtood out against your brother, and hee hath tane you newly into his grace, where it is impoſſible you ſhould take root, but by the faire weather that you make your ſelfe, it is needful that you frame the ſeason for your owne haruest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather be a canker in a hedge, then a rose in his grace, and it better fits my bloud to be disdain’d of all, then to fashion a carriage to rob loue from any: in this (though I cannot be ſaid to be a flattering honeſt man) it must not be denied but I am a plaine dealing villaine, I am trusted with a muſſell, and enfranchisde with a clog, therefore I haue decreed, not to ſing in my cage: if I had my mouth, I would bite: if I had my liberty, I would do my liking: in the meane time, let me be that I am, and ſeeke not to alter me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Can you make no vse of your discontent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I will make all vse of it, for I vse it onely.
Who comes here? what newes Borachio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: I came yonder from a great ſupper, the Prince your brother is royally entertained by Leonato, and I can giue you intelligence of an intended marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Will it ſerue for any Modell to build mischiefe on? What is hee for a foole that betrothes himselfe to vnquietneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mary it is your brothers right hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, the mo’t exquisite Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: A proper ſquier, and who, and who, which way lookes he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mary on Hero, the daughter and Heire of Leo-nato.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: A very forward March-chicke, how came you to this:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Being entertain’d for a perfumer, as I was ſmoa-king a musty roome, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand in ſad conference: I whipt behind the Ar-ras, and there heard it agreed vpon, that the Prince ſhould woœ Hero for himselfe, and hauing obtain’d her, giue her to Count Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, let vs thither, this may proue food to my displeasure, that young ſtart-vp hath all the glorie of my ouerthrow: if I can croſſe him any way, I bleſſe my ſelfe euery way, you are both ſure, and will aſſist mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conr.
SPEECH.LINE: To the death my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs to the great ſupper, their cheere is the greater that I am ſubdued, would the Cooke were of my minde: ſhall we goe proue whats to be done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'll wait vpon your Lordship.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Leonato, his brother, his wife, Hero his daughter, and Beatrice his neece, and a kinsman

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Was not Count Iohn here at ſupper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brother.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw him not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: How tartly that Gentleman lookes, I neuer can ſee him, but I am heart-burn’d an howre after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee were an excellent man that were made iust in the mid-way betweene him and Benedicke, the one is too like an image and ſaies nothing, and the other too like my Ladies eldest ſonne, euermore tatling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Then halfe ſignior Benedicks tongue in Count
Iohns mouth, and halfe Count Iohns melancholy in Sig-nior
Benedicks face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: With a good legge, and a good foot vnckle, and money enough in his purse, ſuch a man would winne any woman in the world, if he could get her good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth Neece, thou wilt neuer get thee a husband, if thou be ſo ſhrewd of thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brother.
SPEECH.LINE: Infaith ſhee's too curst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Too curst is more then curst, I ſhall leſſen Gods ſending that way: for it is ſaid, God ſends a curst Cow ſhort hornes, but to a Cow too curst he ſends none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: So, by being too curst, God will ſend you no hornes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Iust, if he ſend me no husband, for the which bleſſing, I am at him vpon my knees euery morning and euening: Lord, I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face, I had rather lie in the woollen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: You may light vpon a husband that hath no beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould I doe with him? dreſſe him in my apparell, and make him my waiting gentlewoman? he that hath a beard, is more then a youth: and he that hath no beard, is leſſe then a man: and hee that is more then a youth, is not for mee: and he that is leſſe then a man, I am not for him: therefore I will euen take ſixepence in ear-nest of the Berrord, and leade his Apes into hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, goe you into hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: No, but to the gate, and there will the Deuill meete mee like an old Cuckold with hornes on his head, and ſay, get you to heauen Beatrice, get you to heauen, heere's no place for you maids, ſo deliuer I vp my Apes, and away to S[aint]. Peter: for the heauens, hee ſhewes mee where the Batchellers ſit, and there liue wee as merry as the day is long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brother.
SPEECH.LINE: Well neece, I trust you will be rul’d by your father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes faith, it is my cosens dutie to make curt-sie, and ſay, as it please you: but yet for all that cosin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make an other cursie, and ſay, father, as it please me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Well neece, I hope to ſee you one day fitted with a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till God make men of ſome other met-tall then earth, would it not grieue a woman to be ouer-mastred with a peece of valiant dust: to make account of her life to a clod of waiward marle? no vnckle, ile none: Adams ſonnes are my brethren, and truly I hold it a ſinne to match in my kinred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Daughter, remember what I told you, if the
Prince doe ſolicit you in that kinde, you know your an-swere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: The fault will be in the musicke cosin, if you be not wœd in good time: if the Prince bee too impor-tant, tell him there is measure in euery thing, & ſo dance out the answere, for heare me Hero, wooing, wedding, & repenting, is as a Scotch jigge, a measure, and a cinque-pace: the first ſuite is hot and hasty like a Scotch jigge (and full as fantasticall) the wedding manerly modest, (as a measure) full of ſtate & aunchentry, and then comes repentance, and with his bad legs falls into the cinque-pace faster and faster, till he ſinkes into his graue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Cosin you apprehend paſſing ſhrewdly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatrice.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a good eye vnckle, I can ſee a Church by daylight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: The reuellers are entring brother, make good roome.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince, Pedro, Claudio, and Benedicke, and Balthasar, or dumbe Iohn, Maskers with a drum

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, will you walke about with your friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: So you walke ſoftly, and looke ſweetly, and ſay nothing, I am yours for the walke, and especially when I walke away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: With me in your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: I may ſay ſo when I please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: And when please you to ſay ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: When I like your fauour, for God defend the
Lute ſhould be like the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: My visor is Philemons roofe, within the house is Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your visor ſhould be thatcht.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake low if you ſpeake Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I would you did like me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: So would not I for your owne ſake, for I haue manie ill qualities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay my prayers alowd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue you the better, the hearers may cry Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: God match me with a good dauncer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balt.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: And God keepe him out of my ſight when the daunce is done: anſwer Clarke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balt.
SPEECH.LINE: No more words, the Clarke is answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you well enough, you are Signior An-thonio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: At a word, I am not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you by the wagling of your head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: To tell you true, I counterfet him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: You could neuer doe him ſo ill well, vnleſſe you were the very man: here's his dry hand vp & down, you are he, you are he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: At a word I am not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, doe you thinke I doe not know you by your excellent wit? can vertue hide it ſelfe? goe to mumme, you are he, graces will appeare, and there's an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not tell me who told you ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: No, you ſhall pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Not now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: That I was disdainfull, and that I had my good wit out of the hundred merry tales: well, this was Signi-or Benedicke that ſaid ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure you know him well enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, beleeue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Did he neuer make you laugh?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you what is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he is the Princes ieaster, a very dull foole, onely his gift is, in deuising impoſſible ſlanders, none but Libertines delight in him, and the commendation is not in his witte, but in his villanie, for hee both pleaseth men and angers them, and then they laugh at him, and beat him: I am ſure he is in the Fleet, I would he had boorded me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: When I know the Gentleman, Ile tell him what you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Do, do, hee'l but breake a comparison or two on me, which peraduenture (not markt, or not laugh’d at) ſtrikes him into melancholly, and then there's a Par-tridge wing ſaued, for the foole will eate no ſupper that night. We must follow the Leaders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: In euery good thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if they leade to any ill, I will leaue them at the next turning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath withdrawne her father to breake with him about it: the Ladies follow her, and but one visor remaines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Borachio.
SPEECH.LINE: And that is Claudio, I know him by his bea-ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Are not you ſignior Benedicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: You know me well, I am hee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior, you are verie neere my Brother in his loue, he is enamor’d on Hero, I pray you diſſwade him from her, ſhe is no equall for his birth: you may do the part of an honeſt man in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claudio.
SPEECH.LINE: How know you he loues her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard him ſweare his affection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: So did I too, and he ſwore he would marrie her to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let vs to the banquet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus answere I in name of Benedicke,
But heare these ill newes with the eares of Claudio:
‘Tis certaine ſo, the Prince wœs for himselfe:
Friendship is constant in all other things,
Saue in the Office and affaires of loue:
Therefore all hearts in loue vse their owne tongues.
Let euerie eye negotiate for it ſelfe,
And trust no Agent: for beautie is a witch,
Against whose charmes, faith melteth into blood:
This is an accident of hourely proofe,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell therefore Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Count Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, the ſame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, will you goe with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Whither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen to the next Willow, about your own bu-sineſſe, Count. What fashion will you weare the Gar-land off? About your necke, like an Vsurers chaine? Or vnder your arme, like a Lieutenants ſcarfe? You must weare it one way, for the Prince hath got your Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau
SPEECH.LINE: I wish him ioy of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s ſpoken like an honeſt Drouier, ſo they ſel Bullockes: but did you thinke the Prince wold haue ſerued you thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you leaue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Ho now you ſtrike like the blindman, 'twas the boy that ſtole your meate, and you'l beat the post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau
SPEECH.LINE: If it will not be, Ile leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore hurt fowle, now will he creepe into ſedges: But that my Ladie Beatrice ſhould know me, & not know me: the Princes foole! Hah? It may be I goe vnder that title, because I am merrie: yea but ſo I am apt to do my ſelfe wrong: I am not ſo reputed, it is the base (though bitter) disposition of Beatrice, that putt's the world into her person, and ſo giues me out: well, Ile be reuenged as I may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Signior, where's the Count, did you ſee him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth my Lord, I haue played the part of Lady Fame, I found him heere as melancholy as a Lodge in a Warren, I told him, and I thinke, told him true, that your grace had got the will of this young Lady, and I offered him my company to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to binde him a rod, as be-ing worthy to be whipt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: To be whipt, what’s his fault?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: The flat transgreſſion of a Schoole-boy, who being ouer-ioyed with finding a birds nest, ſhewes it his companion, and he ſteales it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou make a trust, a transgreſſion? the transgreſſion is in the ſtealer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet it had not been amiſſe the rod had beene made, and the garland too, for the garland he might haue worne himselfe, and the rod hee might haue bestowed on you, who (as I take it) haue ſtolne his birds nest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: I will but teach them to ſing, and restore them to the owner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: If their ſinging anſwer your ſaying, by my faith you ſay honestly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrell to you, the Gentleman that daunst with her, told her ſhee is much wrong’d by you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe misusde me past the indurance of a block: an oake but with one greene leafe on it, would haue an-swered her: my very visor began to aſſume life, and ſcold with her: ſhee told mee, not thinking I had beene my ſelfe, that I was the Princes Iester, and that I was duller then a great thaw, hudling iest vpon iest, with ſuch im-poſſible conueiance vpon me, that I ſtood like a man at a marke, with a whole army ſhooting at me: ſhee ſpeakes poynyards, and euery word ſtabbes: if her breath were as terrible as terminations, there were no liuing neere her, ſhe would infect to the north ſtarre: I would not marry her, though ſhe were indowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgrest, ſhe would haue made

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hercules
SPEECH.LINE: haue turnd ſpit, yea, and haue cleft his club to make the fire too: come, talke not of her, you ſhall finde her the infernall Ate in good apparell. I would to God ſome ſcholler would coniure her, for certainely while ſhe is heere, a man may liue as quiet in hell, as in a ſanctuary, and people ſinne vpon purpose, because they would goe thither, ſo indeed all disquiet, horror, and perturbation followes her.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Claudio and Beatrice, Leonato, Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke heere ſhe comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Will your Grace command mee any ſeruice to the worlds end? I will goe on the ſlightest arrand now to the Antypodes that you can deuise to ſend me on: I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the furthest inch of Asia: bring you the length of Prester Iohns foot: fetch you a hayre off the great Chams beard: doe you any em-baſſage to the Pigmies, rather then hould three words conference, with this Harpy: you haue no employment for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: None, but to desire your good company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: O God ſir, heeres a dish I loue not, I cannot in-dure this Lady tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Lady, come, you haue lost the heart of
Signior Benedicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed my Lord, hee lent it me a while, and I gaue him vse for it, a double heart for a ſingle one, marry once before he wonne it of mee, with false dice, therefore your Grace may well ſay I haue lost it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue put him downe Lady, you haue put him downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: So I would not he ſhould do me, my Lord, lest
I ſhould prooue the mother of fooles: I haue brought
Count Claudio, whom you ſent me to ſeeke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Count, wherfore are you ſad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſad my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: How then? ſicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: The Count is neither ſad, nor ſicke, nor merry, nor well: but ciuill Count, ciuill as an Orange, and ſome-thing of a iealous complexion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ifaith Lady, I thinke your blazon to be true. though Ile be ſworne, if hee be ſo, his conceit is false: heere Claudio, I haue woœd in thy name, and faire Hero is won, I haue broke with her father, and his good will obtained, name the day of marriage, and God giue thee ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leona.
SPEECH.LINE: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes: his grace hath made the match, & all grace ſay, Amen to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake Count, tis your Qu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence is the perfectest Herault of ioy, I were but little happy if I could ſay, how much? Lady, as you are mine, I am yours, I giue away my ſelfe for you, and doat vpon the exchange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake cosin, or (if you cannot) ſtop his mouth with a kiſſe, and let not him ſpeake neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: In faith Lady you haue a merry heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea my Lord I thanke it, poore foole it keepes on the windy ſide of Care, my coosin tells him in his eare that he is in my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo ſhe doth coosin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Lord for alliance: thus goes euery one to the world but I, and I am ſun-burn’d, I may ſit in a cor-ner and cry, heigh ho for a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I would rather haue one of your fathers getting: hath your Grace ne're a brother like you? your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you haue me? Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: No, my Lord, vnleſſe I might haue another for working-daies, your Grace is too costly to weare euerie day: but I beseech your Grace pardon mee, I was borne to ſpeake all mirth, and no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſilence mo’t offends me, and to be mer-ry, best becomes you, for out of question, you were born in a merry howre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſure my Lord, my Mother cried, but then there was a ſtarre daunst, and vnder that was I borne: co-sins God giue you ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Neece, will you looke to those things I told you of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I cry you mercy Vncle, by your Graces pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth a pleasant ſpirited Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: There's little of the melancholy element in her my Lord, ſhe is neuer ſad, but when ſhe ſleepes, and not euer ſad then: for I haue heard my daughter ſay, ſhe hath often dreamt of vnhappineſſe, and wakt her ſelfe with laughing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee cannot indure to heare tell of a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: O, by no meanes, ſhe mocks all her woœrs out of ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, my Lord, if they were but a weeke married, they would talke themselues madde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Counte Claudio, when meane you to goe to
Church?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow my Lord, Time goes on crutches, till Loue haue all his rites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till monday, my deare ſonne, which is hence a iust ſeuen night, and a time too briefe too, to haue all things anſwer minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, you ſhake the head at ſo long a brea-thing, but I warrant thee Claudio, the time ſhall not goe dully by vs, I will in the interim, vndertake one of Her-cules labors, which is, to bring Signior Benedicke and the Lady Beatrice into a mountaine of affection, th’ one with th’ other, I would faine haue it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister ſuch aſſi-stance as I ſhall giue you direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I am for you, though it cost mee ten nights watchings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: And I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And you to gentle Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: I will doe any modest office, my Lord, to helpe my cosin to a good husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And Benedick is not the vnhopefullest husband that I know: thus farre can I praise him, hee is of a noble ſtraine, of approued valour, and confirm’d honesty, I will teach you how to humour your cosin, that ſhee ſhall fall in loue with Benedicke, and I, with your two helpes, will ſo practise on Benedicke, that in despight of his quicke wit, and his queasie ſtomacke, hee ſhall fall in loue with Beatrice: if wee can doe this, Cupid is no longer an Ar-cher, his glory ſhall be ours, for wee are the onely loue-gods, goe in with me, and I will tell you my drift. Exit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo, the Count Claudio ſhal marry the daugh-ter of Leonato.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bora.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea my Lord, but I can croſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Any barre, any croſſe, any impediment, will be medicinable to me, I am ſicke in displeasure to him, and whatsœuer comes athwart his affection, ranges euenly with mine, how canst thou croſſe this marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not honestly my Lord, but ſo couertly, that no dishonesty ſhall appeare in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me breefely how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I told your Lordship a yeere ſince, how much I am in the fauour of Margaret, the waiting gentle-woman to Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I remember.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: I can at any vnseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to looke out at her Ladies chamber window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: What life is in that, to be the death of this mar-riage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: The poyson of that lies in you to temper, goe you to the Prince your brother, ſpare not to tell him, that hee hath wronged his Honor in marrying the renowned Claudio, whose estimation do you mightily hold vp, to a contaminated ſtale, ſuch a one as Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: What proofe ſhall I make of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Proofe enough, to misuse the Prince, to vexe Claudio, to vndœ Hero, and kill Leonato, looke you for a-ny other iſſue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely to despight them, I will endeauour any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe then, finde me a meete howre, to draw on Pedro and the Count Claudio alone, tell them that you know that Hero loues me, intend a kinde of zeale both to the Prince and Claudio (as in a loue of your brothers honor who hath made this match) and his friends repu-tation, who is thus like to be cosen’d with the ſemblance of a maid, that you haue discouer’d thus: they will ſcarce-ly beleeue this without triall: offer them instances which ſhall beare no leſſe likelihood, than to ſee mee at her chamber window, heare me call Margaret, Hero; heare Margaret terme me Claudio, and bring them to ſee this the very night before the intended wedding, for in the meane time, I will ſo fashion the matter, that Hero ſhall be absent, and there ſhall appeare ſuch ſeeming truths of Herœs disloyaltie, that iealousie ſhall be cal’d aſſurance, and all the preparation ouerthrowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Grow this to what aduerse iſſue it can, I will put it in practise: be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a thousand ducates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Be thou constant in the accusation, and my cun-ning ſhall not ſhame me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I will presentlie goe learne their day of marri-age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: In my chamber window lies a booke, bring it hither to me in the orchard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: I am heere already ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I know that, but I would haue thee hence, and heere againe. I doe much wonder, that one man ſeeing how much another man is a foole, when he dedicates his behauiours to loue, will after hee hath laught at ſuch ſhallow follies in others, become the argument of his owne ſcorne, by falling in loue, & ſuch a man is Claudio. I haue known when there was no musicke with him but the drum and the fife, and now had hee rather heare the taber and the pipe: I haue knowne when he would haue walkt ten mile afoot, to ſee a good armor, and now will he lie ten nights awake caruing the fashion of a new dub-let: he was wont to ſpeake plaine, & to the purpose (like an honeſt man & a ſouldier) and now is he turn’d ortho-graphy, his words are a very fantasticall banquet, iust ſo many ſtrange dishes: may I be ſo conuerted, & ſee with these eyes? I cannot tell, I thinke not: I will not bee ſworne, but loue may transforme me to an oyster, but Ile take my oath on it, till he haue made an oyster of me, he ſhall neuer make me ſuch a foole: one woman is faire, yet I am well: another is wise, yet I am well: another vertu-ous, yet I am well: but till all graces be in one woman, one woman ſhall not come in my grace: rich ſhee ſhall be, that’s certaine: wise, or Ile none: vertuous, or Ile ne-uer cheapen her: faire, or Ile neuer looke on her: milde, or come not neere me: Noble, or not for an Angell: of good discourse: an excellent Musitian, and her haire ſhal be of what colour it please God, hah! the Prince and Monsieur Loue, I will hide me in the Arbor.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince, Leonato, Claudio, and Iacke Wilson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, ſhall we heare this musicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea my good Lord: how ſtill the euening is.
As husht on purpose to grace harmonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: See you where Benedicke hath hid himselfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: O very well my Lord: the musicke ended,
Wee'll fit the kid-foxe with a penny worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Balthasar, wee'll heare that ſong again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: O good my Lord, taxe not ſo bad a voyce,
To ſlander musicke any more then once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the witneſſe ſtill of excellency,
To ſlander Musicke any more then once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the witneſſe ſtill of excellencie,
To put a ſtrange face on his owne perfection,
I pray thee ſing, and let me wœ no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: Because you talke of wooing, I will ſing,
Since many a woœr doth commence his ſuit,
To her he thinkes not worthy, yet he woœs,
Yet will he ſweare he loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay pray thee come,
Or if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Doe it in notes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: Note this before my notes,
Theres not a note of mine that’s worth the noting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Why these are very crotchets that he ſpeaks,
Note notes forsooth, and nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Now diuine aire, now is his ſoule rauisht, is it not ſtrange that ſheepes guts ſhould hale ſoules out of mens bodies? well, a horne for my money when all's done.

Sigh no more Ladies, ſigh no more, Men were deceiuers euer, One foote in Sea, and one on ſhore, To one thing constant neuer, Then ſigh not ſo, but let them goe, And be you blithe and bonnie, Conuerting all your ſounds of wœ, Into hey nony nony. Sing no more ditties, ſing no moe, Of dumps ſo dull and heauy, The fraud of men were euer ſo, Since ſummer first was leauy, Then ſigh not ſo, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth a good ſong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: And an ill ſinger, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, no, no faith, thou ſingst well enough for a ſhift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: And he had been a dog that ſhould haue howld thus, they would haue hang’d him, and I pray God his bad voyce bode no mischiefe, I had as liefe haue heard the night-rauen, come what plague could haue come af-ter it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea marry, dost thou heare Balthasar? I pray thee get vs ſome excellent musick: for to morrow night we would haue it at the Lady Herœs chamber window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth
SPEECH.LINE: The best I can, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo, farewell. Come hither Leonato, what was it you told me of to day, that your Niece Beatrice was in loue with ſignior Benedicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: O I, ſtalke on, ſtalke on, the foule ſits. I did ne-uer thinke that Lady would haue loued any man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor I neither, but mo’t wonderful, that ſhe ſhould ſo dote on Signior Benedicke, whom ſhee hath in all outward behauiours ſeemed euer to abhorre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible? ſits the winde in that corner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth my Lord, I cannot tell what to thinke of it, but that ſhe loues him with an inraged affe-ction, it is past the infinite of thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: May be ſhe doth but counterfeit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith like enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: O God! counterfeit? there was neuer counter-feit of paſſion, came ſo neere the life of paſſion as ſhe dis-couers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Why what effects of paſſion ſhewes ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Baite the hooke well, this fish will bite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: What effects my Lord? ſhee will ſit you, you heard my daughter tell you how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: She did indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: How, how I pray you? you amaze me, I would haue thought her ſpirit had beene inuincible against all aſſaults of affection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: I would haue ſworne it had, my Lord, especially against Benedicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould thinke this a gull, but that the white-bearded fellow ſpeakes it: knauery cannot ſure hide himselfe in ſuch reuerence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath tane th’ infection, hold it vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath ſhee made her affection known to Bene-dicke:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: No, and ſweares ſhe neuer will, that’s her torment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true indeed, ſo your daughter ſaies: ſhall I, ſaies ſhe, that haue ſo oft encountred him with ſcorne, write to him that I loue him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſaies ſhee now when ſhee is beginning to write to him, for ſhee'll be vp twenty times a night, and there will ſhe ſit in her ſmocke, till ſhe haue writ a ſheet of paper: my daughter tells vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Now you talke of a ſheet of paper, I remember a pretty iest your daughter told vs of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: O when ſhe had writ it, & was reading it ouer, ſhe found Benedicke and Beatrice betweene the ſheete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: That.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, raild at her ſelf, that ſhe ſhould be ſo immodest to write, to one that ſhee knew would flout her: I measure him, ſaies ſhe, by my owne ſpirit, for I ſhould flout him if hee writ to mee, yea though I loue him, I ſhould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Then downe vpon her knees ſhe falls, weepes, ſobs, beates her heart, teares her hayre, praies, curses, O ſweet Benedicke, God giue me patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: She doth indeed, my daughter ſaies ſo, and the extasie hath ſo much ouerborne her, that my daughter is ſomtime afeard ſhe will doe a desperate out-rage to her ſelfe, it is very true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: It were good that Benedicke knew of it by ſome other, if ſhe will not discouer it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: To what end? he would but make a ſport of it, and torment the poore Lady worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And he ſhould, it were an almes to hang him, ſhee's an excellent ſweet Lady, and (out of all ſuspition,) ſhe is vertuous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claudio.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhe is exceeding wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: In euery thing, but in louing Benedicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Lord, wisedome and bloud combating in ſo tender a body, we haue ten proofes to one, that bloud hath the victory, I am ſorry for her, as I haue iust cause, being her Vncle, and her Guardian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: I would ſhee had bestowed this dotage on mee, I would haue daft all other respects, and made her halfe my ſelfe: I pray you tell Benedicke of it, and heare what he will ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Were it good thinke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Hero thinkes ſurely ſhe wil die, for ſhe ſaies ſhe will die, if hee loue her not, and ſhee will die ere ſhee make her loue knowne, and ſhe will die if hee woœ her, rather than ſhee will bate one breath of her accustomed croſſeneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: She doth well, if ſhe ſhould make tender of her loue, ‘tis very poſſible hee'l ſcorne it, for the man (as you know all) hath a contemptible ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a very proper man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath indeed a good outward happines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Fore God, and in my minde very wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: He doth indeed ſhew ſome ſparkes that are like wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: And I take him to be valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: As Hector, I aſſure you, and in the managing of quarrels you may ſee hee is wise, for either hee auoydes them with great discretion, or vndertakes them with a Christian-like feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: If hee doe feare God, a must neceſſarilie keepe peace, if hee breake the peace, hee ought to enter into a quarrell with feare and trembling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo will he doe, for the man doth fear God, howsœuer it ſeemes not in him, by ſome large ieasts hee will make: well, I am ſorry for your niece, ſhall we goe ſee Benedicke, and tell him of her loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer tell him, my Lord, let her weare it out with good counsell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that’s impoſſible, ſhe may weare her heart out first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, we will heare further of it by your daugh-ter, let it coole the while, I loue Benedicke well, and I could wish he would modestly examine himselfe, to ſee how much he is vnworthy to haue ſo good a Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, will you walke? dinner is ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If he do not doat on her vpon this, I wil neuer trust my expectation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let there be the ſame Net ſpread for her, and that must your daughter and her gentlewoman carry: the ſport will be, when they hold one an opinion of ano-thers dotage, and no ſuch matter, that’s the Scene that I would ſee, which will be meerely a dumbe ſhew: let vs ſend her to call him into dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: This can be no tricke, the conference was ſadly borne, they haue the truth of this from Hero, they ſeeme to pittie the Lady: it ſeemes her affections haue the full bent: loue me? why it must be requited: I heare how I am censur’d, they ſay I will beare my ſelfe proudly, if I perceiue the loue come from her: they ſay too, that ſhe will rather die than giue any ſigne of affection: I did ne-uer thinke to marry, I must not ſeeme proud, happy are they that heare their detractions, and can put them to mending: they ſay the Lady is faire, ‘tis a truth, I can beare them witneſſe: and vertuous, tis ſo, I cannot re-prooue it, and wise, but for louing me, by my troth it is no addition to her witte, nor no great argument of her folly; for I wil be horribly in loue with her, I may chance haue ſome odde quirkes and remnants of witte broken on mee, because I haue rail’d ſo long against marriage: but doth not the appetite alter? a man loues the meat in his youth, that he cannot indure in his age. Shall quips and ſentences, and these paper bullets of the braine awe a man from the careere of his humour? No, the world must be peopled. When I ſaid I would die a batcheler, I did not think I ſhould liue till I were maried, here comes Beatrice: by this day, ſhee's a faire Lady, I doe ſpie ſome markes of loue in her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Against my wil I am ſent to bid you come in to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Beatrice, I thanke you for your paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I tooke no more paines for those thankes, then you take paines to thanke me, if it had been painefull, I would not haue come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: You take pleasure then in the meſſage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea iust ſo much as you may take vpon a kniues point, and choake a daw withall: you haue no ſtomacke ſignior, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, against my will I am ſent to bid you come into dinner: there's a double meaning in that: I tooke no more paines for those thankes then you took paines to thanke me, that’s as much as to ſay, any paines that I take for you is as easie as thankes: if I do not take pitty of her I am a villaine, if I doe not loue her I am a Iew, I will goe get her picture.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hero and two Gentlemen, Margaret, and Vrsula.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Margaret runne thee to the parlour,
There ſhalt thou finde my Cosin Beatrice,
Proposing with the Prince and Claudio,
Whisper her eare, and tell her I and Vrsula,
Walke in the Orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her, ſay that thou ouer-heardst vs,
And bid her ſteale into the pleached bower,
Where hony-suckles ripened by the ſunne,
Forbid the ſunne to enter: like fauourites,
Made proud by Princes, that aduance their pride,
Against that power that bred it, there will ſhe hide her,
To listen our purpose, this is thy office,
Beare thee well in it, and leaue vs alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marg.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make her come I warrant you presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Vrsula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley vp and downe,
Our talke must onely be of Benedicke,
When I doe name him, let it be thy part,
To praise him more then euer man did merit,
My talke to thee must be how Benedicke
Is ſicke in loue with Beatrice; of this matter,
Is little Cupids crafty arrow made,
That onely wounds by heare-say: now begin,
For looke where Beatrice like a Lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to heare our conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrs.
SPEECH.LINE: The pleasant'st angling is to ſee the fish
Cut with her golden ores the ſiluer ſtreame,
And greedily deuoure the treacherous baite:
So angle we for Beatrice, who euen now,
Is couched in the wood-bine couerture,
Feare you not my part of the Dialogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: Then go we neare her that her eare loose nothing,
Of the false ſweete baite that we lay for it:
No truely Vrsula, ſhe is too disdainfull,
I know her ſpirits are as coy and wilde,
As Haggerds of the rocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: But are you ſure,
That Benedicke loues Beatrice ſo intirely?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſaies the Prince, and my new trothed Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrs.
SPEECH.LINE: And did they bid you tell her of it, Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: They did intreate me to acquaint her of it,
But I perswaded them, if they lou’d Benedicke,
To wish him wrastle with affection,
And neuer to let Beatrice know of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: Why did you ſo, doth not the Gentleman
Deserue as full as fortunate a bed,
As euer Beatrice ſhall couch vpon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: O God of loue! I know he doth deserue,
As much as may be yeelded to a man:
But Nature neuer fram’d a womans heart,
Of prowder ſtuffe then that of Beatrice:
Disdaine and Scorne ride ſparkling in her eyes,
Mis-prizing what they looke on, and her wit
Values it ſelfe ſo highly, that to her
All matter else ſeemes weake: ſhe cannot loue,
Nor take no ſhape nor proiect of affection,
Shee is ſo ſelfe indeared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure I thinke ſo,
And therefore certainely it were not good
She knew his loue, lest ſhe make ſport at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Why you ſpeake truth, I neuer yet ſaw man,
How wise, how noble, yong, how rarely featur’d.
But ſhe would ſpell him backward: if faire fac’d,
She would ſweare the gentleman ſhould be her ſister:
If blacke, why Nature drawing of an anticke,
Made a foule blot: if tall, a launce ill headed:
If low, an agot very vildlie cut:
If ſpeaking, why a vane blowne with all windes:
If ſilent, why a blocke moued with none.
So turnes ſhe euery man the wrong ſide out,
And neuer giues to Truth and Vertue, that
Which ſimpleneſſe and merit purchaseth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure, ſure, ſuch carping is not commendable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not to be ſo odde, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable,
But who dare tell her ſo? if I ſhould ſpeake,
She would mocke me into ayre, O ſhe would laugh me
Out of my ſelfe, preſſe me to death with wit,
Therefore let Benedicke like couered fire,
Consume away in ſighes, waste inwardly:
It were a better death, to die with mockes,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet tell her of it, heare what ſhee will ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: No, rather I will goe to Benedicke,
And counsaile him to fight against his paſſion,
And truly Ile deuise ſome honeſt ſlanders,
To ſtaine my cosin with, one doth not know,
How much an ill word may impoison liking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: O doe not doe your cosin ſuch a wrong,
She cannot be ſo much without true iudgement,
Hauing ſo ſwift and excellent a wit
As ſhe is prisde to haue, as to refuse
So rare a Gentleman as ſignior Benedicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: He is the onely man of Italy,
Alwaies excepted, my deare Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you be not angry with me, Madame,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedicke,
For ſhape, for bearing argument and valour,
Goes formost in report through Italy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed he hath an excellent good name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: His excellence did earne it ere he had it:
When are you married Madame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Why euerie day to morrow, come goe in,
Ile ſhew thee ſome attires, and haue thy counsell,
Which is the best to furnish me to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee's tane I warrant you,
We haue caught her Madame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: If it proue ſo, then louing goes by haps,
Some Cupid kills with arrowes, ſome with traps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: What fire is in mine eares? can this be true?
Stand I condemn’d for pride and ſcorne ſo much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adew,
No glory liues behinde the backe of ſuch.
And Benedicke, loue on, I will requite thee,
Taming my wilde heart to thy louing hand:
If thou dost loue, my kindneſſe ſhall incite thee
To binde our loues vp in a holy band.
For others ſay thou dost deserue, and I
Beleeue it better then reportingly.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince, Claudio, Benedicke, and Leonato.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe but ſtay till your marriage be consum-mate, and then go I toward Arragon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile bring you thither my Lord, if you'l vouch-safe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that would be as great a ſoyle in the new gloſſe of your marriage, as to ſhew a childe his new coat and forbid him to weare it, I will onely bee bold with Benedicke for his companie, for from the crowne of his head, to the ſole of his foot, he is all mirth, he hath twice or thrice cut Cupids bow-string, and the little hang-man dare not ſhoot at him, he hath a heart as ſound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinkes, his tongue ſpeakes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Gallants, I am not as I haue bin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſay I, methinkes you are ſadder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope he be in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him truant, there's no true drop of bloud in him to be truly toucht with loue, if he be ſad, he wants money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue the tooth-ach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What? ſigh for the tooth-ach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is but a humour or a worme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, euery one cannot master a griefe, but hee that has it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſay I, he is in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no appearance of fancie in him, vnleſſe it be a fancy that he hath to ſtrange disguises, as to bee a Dutchman to day, a Frenchman to morrow: vnleſſe hee haue a fancy to this foolery, as it appeares hee hath, hee is no foole for fancy, as you would haue it to appeare he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be not in loue with ſome woman, there is no beleeuing old ſignes, a brushes his hat a mornings, What ſhould that bode?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath any man ſeene him at the Barbers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: No, but the Barbers man hath beene ſeen with him, and the olde ornament of his cheeke hath alreadie ſtuft tennis balls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed he lookes yonger than hee did, by the loſſe of a beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay a rubs himselfe with Ciuit, can you ſmell him out by that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to ſay, the ſweet youth's in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And when was he wont to wash his face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, or to paint himselfe? for the which I heare what they ſay of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but his iesting ſpirit, which is now crept into a lute-string, and now gouern’d by ſtops.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed that tels a heauy tale for him: conclude, he is in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but I know who loues him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: That would I know too, I warrant one that knowes him not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, and his ill conditions, and in despight of all, dies for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee ſhall be buried with her face vpwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet is this no charme for the tooth-ake, old ſig-nior, walke aside with mee, I haue ſtudied eight or nine wise words to ſpeake to you, which these hobby-horses must not heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: For my life to breake with him about Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis euen ſo, Hero and Margaret haue by this played their parts with Beatrice, and then the two Beares will not bite one another when they meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord and brother, God ſaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good den brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If your leisure ſeru’d, I would ſpeake with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: In priuate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If it please you, yet Count Claudio may heare, for what I would ſpeake of, concernes him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Basta.
SPEECH.LINE: Meanes your Lordship to be married to mor-row?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You know he does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not that when he knowes what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be any impediment, I pray you disco-uer it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: You may thinke I loue you not, let that appeare hereafter, and ayme better at me by that I now will ma-nifest, for my brother (I thinke, he holds you well, and in deareneſſe of heart) hath holpe to effect your ensuing marriage: ſurely ſute ill ſpent, and labour ill bestowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: I came hither to tell you, and circumstances ſhortned, (for ſhe hath beene too long a talking of) the Lady is disloyall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Who Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſhee, Leonatœs Hero, your Hero, euery mans Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Disloyall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: The word is too good to paint out her wicked-neſſe, I could ſay ſhe were worse, thinke you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it: wonder not till further war-rant: goe but with mee to night, you ſhal ſee her cham-ber window entred, euen the night before her wedding day, if you loue her, then to morrow wed her: But it would better fit your honour to change your minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: May this be ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Princ.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not thinke it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If you dare not trust that you ſee, confeſſe not that you know: if you will follow mee, I will ſhew you enough, and when you haue ſeene more, & heard more, proceed accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If I ſee any thing to night, why I ſhould not marry her to morrow in the congregation, where I ſhold wedde, there will I ſhame her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And as I woœd for thee to obtaine her, I will ioyne with thee to disgrace her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I will disparage her no farther, till you are my witneſſes, beare it coldly but till night, and let the iſſue ſhew it ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: O day vntowardly turned!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: O mischiefe ſtrangelie thwarting!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: O plague right well preuented! ſo will you ſay, when you haue ſeene the ſequele. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Dogbery and his compartner with the watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you good men and true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verg.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, or else it were pitty but they ſhould ſuffer ſaluation body and ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they ſhould haue any allegiance in them, being chosen for the Princes watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, giue them their charge, neighbour
Dogbery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: First, who thinke you the mo’t desartleſſe man to be Constable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.1.
SPEECH.LINE: Hugh Ote-cake ſir, or George Sea-coale, for they can write and reade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither neighbour Sea-coale, God hath blest you with a good name: to be a wel-fauoured man, is the gift of Fortune, but to write and reade, comes by Nature. Watch 2. Both which Master Constable

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue: I knew it would be your answere: well, for your fauour ſir, why giue God thankes, & make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appeare when there is no need of ſuch vanity, you are thought heere to be the mo’t ſensleſſe and fit man for the Constable of the watch: therefore beare you the lan-thorne: this is your charge: You ſhall comprehend all vagrom men, you are to bid any man ſtand in the Prin-ces name. Watch 2. How if a will not ſtand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then take no note of him, but let him go, and presently call the rest of the Watch together, and thanke God you are ridde of a knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: If he will not ſtand when he is bidden, hee is none of the Princes ſubiects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and they are to meddle with none but the Princes ſubiects: you ſhall also make no noise in the ſtreetes: for, for the Watch to babble and talke, is mo’t tollerable, and not to be indured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: We will rather ſleepe than talke, wee know what belongs to a Watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Why you ſpeake like an ancient and mo’t quiet watchman, for I cannot ſee how ſleeping ſhould offend: only haue a care that your bills be not ſtolne: well, you are to call at all the Alehouses, and bid them that are drunke get them to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: How if they will not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then let them alone till they are ſober, if they make you not then the better answere, you may ſay, they are not the men you tooke them for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: If you meet a theefe, you may ſuspect him, by vertue of your office, to be no true man: and for ſuch kinde of men, the leſſe you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your honesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: If wee know him to be a thiefe, ſhall wee not lay hands on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly by your office you may, but I think they that touch pitch will be defil’d: the mo’t peaceable way for you, if you doe take a theefe, is, to let him ſhew him-ſelfe what he is, and ſteale out of your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ver.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue bin alwaies cal’d a merciful ma[n] partner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man who hath anie honestie in him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: If you heare a child crie in the night you must call to the nurse, and bid her ſtill it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: How if the nurse be asleepe and will not heare vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then depart in peace, and let the childe wake her with crying, for the ewe that will not heare her Lambe when it baes, will neuer answere a calfe when he bleates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis verie true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the end of the charge: you constable are to present the Princes owne person, if you meete the Prince in the night, you may ſtaie him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay birladie that I thinke a cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue ſhillings to one on't with anie man that knowes the Statutes, he may ſtaie him, marrie not with-out the prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offence to ſtay a man against his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: Birladie I thinke it be ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ah ha, well masters good night, and there be anie matter of weight chances, call vp me, keepe your fellowes counsailes, and your owne, and good night, come neighbour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Well masters, we heare our charge, let vs go ſit here vpon the Church bench till two, and then all to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: One word more, honeſt neighbors. I pray you watch about ſignior Leonatœs doore, for the wedding be-ing there to morrow, there is a great coyle to night, adiew, be vigitant I beseech you. Exeunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: What, Conrade?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ſtir not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Conrade I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Here man, I am at thy elbow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mas and my elbow itcht, I thought there would a ſcabbe follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: I will owe thee an answere for that, and now forward with thy tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand thee close then vnder this penthouse, for it driſſels raine, and I will, like a true drunkard, vtter all to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Some treason masters, yet ſtand close.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore know, I haue earned of Don Iohn a thousand Ducates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it poſſible that anie villanie ſhould be ſo deare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhould'st rather aske if it were poſſible a-nie villanie ſhould be ſo rich? for when rich villains haue neede of poore ones, poore ones may make what price they will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhewes thou art vnconfirm’d, thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloake, is no-thing to a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, it is apparell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane the fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes the fashion is the fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Tuſh, I may as well ſay the foole's the foole, but ſeest thou not what a deformed theefe this fashion is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: I know that deformed, a has bin a vile theefe, this vii. yeares, a goes vp and downe like a gentle man: I remember his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Did'st thou not heare ſome bodie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: No, 'twas the vaine on the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Seest thou not (I ſay) what a deformed thiefe this fashion is, how giddily a turnes about all the Hot-blouds, betweene, foureteene & fiue & thirtie, ſometimes fashioning them like Pharaœs ſouldiours in the rechie painting, ſometime like god Bels priests in the old Church window, ſometime like the ſhauen Hercules in the ſmircht worm-eaten tapestrie, where his cod-peece ſeemes as maſſie as his club.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
