SPEECH.LINE: All this I ſee, and ſee that the fashion weares out more apparrell then the man; but art not thou thy ſelfe giddie with the fashion too that thou hast ſhifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo neither, but know that I haue to night woœd Margaret the Lady Herœs gentle-woman, by the name of Hero, ſhe leanes me out at her mistris chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good night: I tell this tale vildly. I ſhould first tell thee how the Prince Claudio and my Master planted, and placed, and poſſeſſed by my Master Don Iohn, ſaw a far off in the Orchard this amiable incounter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: And thought thy Margaret was Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the diuell my Master knew ſhe was Margaret and partly by his oathes, which first poſſest them, partly by the darke night which did deceiue them, but chiefely, by my villa-nie, which did confirme any ſlander that Don Iohn had made, away went Claudio enraged, ſwore hee would meete her as he was apointed next morning at the Tem-ple, and there, before the whole congregation ſhame her with what he ſaw o’re night, and ſend her home againe without a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.1.
SPEECH.LINE: We charge you in the Princes name ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.2.
SPEECH.LINE: Call vp the right master Constable, we haue here recouered the mo’t dangerous peece of lechery, that euer was knowne in the Common-wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.1.
SPEECH.LINE: And one Deformed is one of them, I know him, a weares a locke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conr.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters, masters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.2.
SPEECH.LINE: Youle be made bring deformed forth I war-rant you,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conr.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters, neuer ſpeake, we charge you, let vs o-bey you to goe with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: We are like to proue a goodly commoditie, be-ing taken vp of these mens bils.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conr.
SPEECH.LINE: A commoditie in question I warrant you, come weele obey you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hero, and Margaret, and Vrsula.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Vrsula wake my cosin Beatrice, and de-sire her to rise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SPEECH.LINE: I will Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: And bid her come hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrs.
SPEECH.LINE: Well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth I thinke your other rebato were better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: No pray thee good Meg, Ile weare this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marg.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth's not ſo good, and I warrant your cosin will ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: My cosin's a foole, and thou art another, ile weare none but this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I like the new tire within excellently, if the haire were a thought browner: and your gown's a mo’t rare fashion yfaith, I ſaw the Dutcheſſe of Millaines gowne that they praise ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: O that exceedes they ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth's but a night-gowne in respect of yours, cloth a gold and cuts, and lac’d with ſiluer, ſet with pearles, downe ſleeues, ſide ſleeues, and ſkirts, round vn-derborn with a blewish tinsel, but for a fine queint grace-full and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: God giue mee ioy to weare it, for my heart is exceeding heauy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marga.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twill be heauier ſoone, by the waight of a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie vpon thee, art not asham’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marg.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what Lady? of ſpeaking honourably? is not marriage honourable in a beggar? is not your Lord honourable without marriage? I thinke you would haue me ſay, ſauing your reuerence a husband: and bad thin-king doe not wrest true ſpeaking, Ile offend no body, is there any harme in the heauier for a husband? none I thinke, and it be the right husband, and the right wife, otherwise ‘tis light and not heauy, aske my Lady Beatrice else, here ſhe comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Coze.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow ſweet Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now? do you ſpeake in the ſick tune?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I am out of all other tune, me thinkes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Claps into Light a loue, (that goes without a burden,) do you ſing it and Ile dance it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Ye Light aloue with your heeles, then if your husband haue ſtables enough, you'll looke he ſhall lacke no barnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: O illegitimate construction! I ſcorne that with my heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis almost fiue a clocke cosin, ‘tis time you were ready, by my troth I am exceeding ill, hey ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: For a hauke, a horse, or a husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: For the letter that begins them all, H.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, and you be not turn’d Turke, there's no more ſayling by the ſtarre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes the foole trow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing I, but God ſend euery one their harts desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: These gloues the Count ſent mee, they are an excellent perfume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſtuft cosin, I cannot ſmell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: A maid and ſtuft! there's goodly catching of colde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: O God helpe me, God help me, how long haue you profest apprehension?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Euer ſince you left it, doth not my wit become me rarely?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſeene enough, you ſhould weare it in your cap, by my troth I am ſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Get you ſome of this distill’d carduus benedictus and lay it to your heart, it is the onely thing for a qualm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: There thou prick'st her with a thiſſell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Benedictus, why benedictus? you haue ſome mo-rall in this benedictus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Morall? no by my troth, I haue no morall mea-ning, I meant plaine holy thiſſell, you may thinke per-chance that I thinke you are in loue, nay birlady I am not ſuch a foole to thinke what I list, nor I list not to thinke what I can, nor indeed, I cannot thinke, if I would thinke my hart out of thinking, that you are in loue, or that you will be in loue, or that you can be in loue: yet Benedicke was ſuch another, and now is he become a man, he ſwore hee would neuer marry, and yet now in despight of his heart he eates his meat without grudging, and how you may be conuerted I know not, but me thinkes you looke with your eies as other women doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: What pace is this that thy tongue keepes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a false gallop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, withdraw, the Prince, the Count, ſig-nior Benedicke, Don Iohn, and all the gallants of the towne are come to fetch you to Church.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe me to dreſſe mee good coze, good Meg, good Vrsula.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Leonato, and the Constable, and the Headborough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you with mee, honeſt neigh-bour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Mary ſir I would haue ſome confidence with you, that decernes you nearely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Briefe I pray you, for you ſee it is a busie time with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Mary this it is ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Headb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes in truth it is ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: What is it my good friends?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Do.
SPEECH.LINE: Goodman Verges ſir ſpeakes a little of the matter, an old man ſir, and his wits are not ſo blunt, as God helpe I would desire they were, but infaith honeſt as the ſkin betweene his browes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Head.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes I thank God, I am as honeſt as any man li-uing, that is an old man, and no honester then I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Comparisons are odorous, palabras, neigh-bour
Verges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Neighbours, you are tedious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: It pleases your worship to ſay ſo, but we are the poore Dukes officers, but truely for mine owne part, if I were as tedious as a King I could finde in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: All thy tediousneſſe on me, ah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and 'twere a thousand times more than ‘tis, for I heare as good exclamation on your Wor-ship as of any man in the Citie, and though I bee but a poore man, I am glad to heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Head.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I would faine know what you haue to ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Head.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir our watch to night, excepting your worships presence, haue tane a couple of as arrant knaues as any in Meſſina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: A good old man ſir, hee will be talking as they ſay, when the age is in, the wit is out, God helpe vs, it is a world to ſee: well ſaid yfaith neighbour Verges, well, God's a good man, and two men ride of a horse, one must ride behinde, an honeſt ſoule yfaith ſir, by my troth he is, as euer broke bread, but God is to bee wor-shipt, all men are not alike, alas good neighbour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed neighbour he comes too ſhort of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Do.
SPEECH.LINE: Gifts that God giues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I must leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.Dog.
SPEECH.LINE: One word ſir, our watch ſir haue indeede comprehended two aspitious persons, & we would haue them this morning examined before your worship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Take their examination your ſelfe, and bring it me, I am now in great haste, as may appeare vnto you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſuffigance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon
SPEECH.LINE: Drinke ſome wine ere you goe: fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſenger.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, they ſtay for you to giue your daughter to her husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile wait vpon them, I am ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe good partner, goe get you to Francis Sea-coale, bid him bring his pen and inkehorne to the Gaole: we are now to examine those men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Verges.
SPEECH.LINE: And we must doe it wisely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee will ſpare for no witte I warrant you: heere's that ſhall driue ſome to a non-come, on-ly get the learned writer to ſet downe our excommuni-cation, and meet me at the Iaile.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince, Bastard, Leonato, Frier, Claudio, Benedicke, Hero, and Beatrice

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Frier Francis, be briefe, onely to the plaine forme of marriage, and you ſhal recount their par-ticular duties afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: You come hither, my Lord, to marry this Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: To be married to her: Frier, you come to mar-rie her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, you come hither to be married to this
Count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: If either of you know any inward impediment why you ſhould not be conioyned, I charge you on your ſoules to vtter it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you anie, Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: None my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you anie, Count?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare make his anſwer, None.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: O what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: How now! interiections? why then, ſome be of laughing, as ha, ha, he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand thee by Frier, father, by your leaue,
Will you with free and vnconstrained ſoule
Giue me this maid your daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: As freely ſonne as God did giue her me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: And what haue I to giue you back, whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, vnleſſe you render her againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulnes:
There Leonato, take her backe againe,
Giue not this rotten Orenge to your friend,
Shee's but the ſigne and ſemblance of her honour:
Behold how like a maid ſhe blushes heere!
O what authoritie and ſhew of truth
Can cunning ſinne couer it ſelfe withall!
Comes not that bloud, as modest euidence,
To witneſſe ſimple Vertue? would you not ſweare
All you that ſee her, that ſhe were a maide,
By these exterior ſhewes? But ſhe is none:
She knowes the heat of a luxurious bed:
Her blush is guiltineſſe, not modestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: What doe you meane, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Not to be married,
Not to knit my ſoule to an approued wanton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Deere my Lord, if you in your owne proofe,
Haue vanquisht the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I know what you would ſay: if I haue knowne
(her,
You will ſay, ſhe did imbrace me as a husband,
And ſo extenuate the forehand ſinne: No Leonato,
I neuer tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his ſister, ſhewed
Bashfull ſinceritie and comely loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſeem’d I euer otherwise to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Out on thee ſeeming, I will write against it,
You ſeeme to me as Diane in her Orbe,
As chaste as is the budde ere it be blowne:
But you are more intemperate in your blood,
Than Venus, or those pampred animalls,
That rage in ſauage ſensualitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Is my Lord well, that he doth ſpeake ſo wide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete Prince, why ſpeake not you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould I ſpeake?
I ſtand dishonour’d that haue gone about,
To linke my deare friend to a common ſtale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Are these things ſpoken, or doe I but dreame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, they are ſpoken, and these things are true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: This lookes not like a nuptiall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: True, O God!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Leonato, ſtand I here?
Is this the Prince? is this the Princes brother?
Is this face Herœs? are our eies our owne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: All this is ſo, but what of this my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me but moue one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power,
That you haue in her, bid her anſwer truly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: I charge thee doe, as thou art my childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: O God defend me how am I beset,
What kinde of catechizing call you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: To make you anſwer truly to your name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not Hero? who can blot that name
With any iust reproach?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry that can Hero,
Hero it ſelfe can blot out Herœs vertue.
What man was he, talkt with you yesternight,
Out at your window betwixt twelue and one?
Now if you are a maid, anſwer to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: I talkt with no man at that howre my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then you are no maiden. Leonato,
I am ſorry you must heare: vpon mine honor,
My ſelfe, my brother, and this grieued Count
Did ſee her, heare her, at that howre last night,
Talke with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeed mo’t like a liberall villaine,
Confest the vile encounters they haue had
A thousand times in ſecret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, they are not to be named my Lord,
Not to be ſpoken of,
There is not chastitie enough in language,
Without offence to vtter them: thus pretty Lady
I am ſorry for thy much misgouernment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou beene
If halfe thy outward graces had beene placed
About thy thoughts and counsailes of thy heart?
But fare thee well, mo’t foule, mo’t faire, farewell
Thou pure impiety, and impious puritie,
For thee Ile locke vp all the gates of Loue,
And on my eie-lids ſhall Coniecture hang,
To turne all beauty into thoughts of harme,
And neuer ſhall it more be gracious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath no mans dagger here a point for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now cosin, wherfore ſink you down?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let vs go: these things come thus to light,
Smother her ſpirits vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: How doth the Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead I thinke, helpe vncle,
Hero, why Hero, Vncle, Signor Benedicke, Frier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: O Fate! take not away thy heauy hand,
Death is the fairest couer for her ſhame
That may be wisht for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SPEECH.LINE: How now cosin Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue comfort Ladie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou looke vp?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, wherefore ſhould ſhe not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherfore? Why doth not euery earthly thing
Cry ſhame vpon her? Could ſhe heere denie
The ſtorie that is printed in her blood?
Do not liue Hero, do not ope thine eyes:
For did I thinke thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy ſpirits were ſtronger then thy ſhames,
My ſelfe would on the reward of reproaches
Strike at thy life. Grieu’d I, I had but one?
Chid I, for that at frugal Natures frame?
O one too much by thee: why had I one?
Why euer was't thou louelie in my eies?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Tooke vp a beggars iſſue at my gates,
Who ſmeered thus, and mir’d with infamie,
I might haue ſaid, no part of it is mine:
This ſhame deriues it ſelfe from vnknowne loines,
But mine, and mine I lou’d, and mine I prais’d,
And mine that I was proud on mine ſo much,
That I my ſelfe, was to my ſelfe not mine:
Valewing of her, why ſhe, O ſhe is falne
Into a pit of Inke, that the wide ſea
Hath drops too few to wash her cleane againe,
And ſalt too little, which may ſeason giue
To her foule tainted flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſir, be patient: for my part, I am ſo attired in wonder, I know not what to ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: O on my ſoule my cosin is belied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladie, were you her bedfellow last night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: No, truly: not although vntill last night,
I haue this tweluemonth bin her bedfellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Confirm’d, confirm’d, O that is ſtronger made
Which was before barr’d vp with ribs of iron.
Would the Princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who lou’d her ſo, that ſpeaking of her foulneſſe,
Wash’d it with teares? Hence from her, let her die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me a little, for I haue onely bene ſilent ſo long, and giuen way vnto this course of fortune, by no-ting of the Ladie, I haue markt. A thousand blushing apparitions, To ſtart into her face, a thousand innocent ſhames, In Angel whiteneſſe beare away those blushes, And in her eie there hath appear’d a fire To burne the errors that these Princes hold Against her maiden truth. Call me a foole, Trust not my reading, nor my obseruations, Which with experimental ſeale doth warrant The tenure of my booke: trust not my age, My reuerence, calling, nor diuinitie, If this ſweet Ladie lye not guiltleſſe heere, Vnder ſome biting error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Friar, it cannot be:
Thou ſeest that all the Grace that ſhe hath left,
Is, that ſhe wil not adde to her damnation,
A ſinne of periury, ſhe not denies it:
Why ſeek'st thou then to couer with excuse,
That which appeares in proper nakedneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladie, what man is he you are accus’d of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: They know that do accuse me, I know none:
If I know more of any man aliue
Then that which maiden modestie doth warrant,
Let all my ſinnes lacke mercy. O my Father,
Proue you that any man with me conuerst,
At houres vnmeete, or that I yesternight
Maintain’d the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: There is ſome ſtrange misprision in the Princes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Two of them haue the verie bent of honor,
And if their wisedomes be misled in this:
The practise of it liues in Iohn the bastard,
Whose ſpirits toile in frame of villanies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not: if they ſpeake but truth of her,
These hands ſhall teare her: If they wrong her honour,
The proudest of them ſhall wel heare of it.
Time hath not yet ſo dried this bloud of mine,
Nor age ſo eate vp my inuention,
Nor Fortune made ſuch hauocke of my meanes,
Nor my bad life reft me ſo much of friends,
But they ſhall finde, awak’d in ſuch a kinde,
Both ſtrength of limbe, and policie of minde,
Ability in meanes, and choise of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Pause awhile:
And let my counsell ſway you in this case,
Your daughter heere the Princeſſe (left for dead)
Let her awhile be ſecretly kept in,
And publish it, that ſhe is dead indeed:
Maintaine a mourning ostentation,
And on your Families old monument,
Hang mournfull Epitaphes, and do all rites,
That appertaine vnto a buriall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall become of this? What wil this do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this wel carried, ſhall on her behalfe,
Change ſlander to remorse, that is ſome good,
But not for that dreame I on this ſtrange course,
But on this trauaile looke for greater birth:
She dying, as it must be ſo maintain’d,
Vpon the instant that ſhe was accus’d,
Shal be lamented, pittied, and excus’d
Of euery hearer: for it ſo fals out,
That what we haue, we prize not to the worth,
Whiles we enioy it; but being lack’d and lost,
Why then we racke the value, then we finde
The vertue that poſſeſſion would not ſhew vs
Whiles it was ours, ſo will it fare with Claudio:
When he ſhal heare ſhe dyed vpon his words,
Th’ Idea of her life ſhal ſweetly creepe
Into his ſtudy of imagination.
And euery louely Organ of her life,
Shall come apparel’d in more precious habite:
More mouing delicate, and ful of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his ſoule
Then when ſhe liu’d indeed: then ſhal he mourne,
If euer Loue had interest in his Liuer,
And wish he had not ſo accused her:
No, though he thought his accusation true:
Let this be ſo, and doubt not but ſucceſſe
Wil fashion the euent in better ſhape,
Then I can lay it downe in likelihood.
But if all ayme but this be leuelld false,
The ſupposition of the Ladies death,
Will quench the wonder of her infamie.
And if it ſort not well, you may conceale her
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In ſome reclusiue and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, mindes and iniuries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Leonato, let the Frier aduise you,
And though you know my inwardneſſe and loue
Is very much vnto the Prince and Claudio.
Yet, by mine honor, I will deale in this,
As ſecretly and iustlie, as your ſoule
Should with your bodie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Being that I flow in greefe,
The ſmallest twine may lead me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well consented, presently away,
For to ſtrange ſores, ſtrangely they ſtraine the cure,
Come Lady, die to liue, this wedding day
Perhaps is but prolong’d, haue patience & endure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady Beatrice, haue you wept all this while?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and I will weepe a while longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not desire that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue no reason, I doe it freely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Surelie I do beleeue your fair cosin is wrong’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, how much might the man deserue of mee that would right her!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there any way to ſhew ſuch friendship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: A verie euen way, but no ſuch friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: May a man doe it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a mans office, but not yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe loue nothing in the world ſo well as you, is not that ſtrange?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: As ſtrange as the thing I know not, it were as poſſible for me to ſay, I loued nothing ſo well as you, but beleeue me not, and yet I lie not, I confeſſe nothing, nor I deny nothing, I am ſorry for my cousin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: By my ſword Beatrice thou lou'st me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not ſweare by it and eat it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſweare by it that you loue mee, and I will make him eat it that ſayes I loue not you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not eat your word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: With no ſawce that can be deuised to it, I pro-test
I loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then God forgiue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: What offence ſweet Beatrice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue ſtayed me in a happy howre, I was a-bout to protest I loued you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: And doe it with all thy heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue you with ſo much of my heart, that none is left to protest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, bid me doe any thing for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Kill Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, not for the wide world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You kill me to denie, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Tarrie ſweet Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I am gone, though I am heere, there is no loue in you, nay I pray you let me goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Infaith I will goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'll be friends first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: You dare easier be friends with mee, than fight with mine enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Claudio thine enemie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Is a not approued in the height a villaine, that hath ſlandered, ſcorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O that I were a man! what, beare her in hand vntill they come to take hands, and then with publike accusation vncouered ſlander, vnmittigated rancour? O God that I were a man! I would eat his heart in the market-place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Talke with a man out at a window, a proper ſaying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Hero, ſhe is wrong’d, ſhee is ſlandered, ſhe is vndone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Beat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Princes and Counties! ſurelie a Princely testi-monie, a goodly Count, Comfect, a ſweet Gallant ſure-lie, O that I were a man for his ſake! or that I had any friend would be a man for my ſake! But manhood is mel-ted into cursies, valour into complement, and men are onelie turned into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules, that only tells a lie, and ſweares it: I cannot be a man with wishing, therfore I will die a wo-man with grieuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Tarry good Beatrice, by this hand I loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Vse it for my loue ſome other way then ſwea-ring by it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke you in your ſoule the Count Claudio hath wrong’d Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, as ſure as I haue a thought, or a ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough, I am engagde, I will challenge him, I will kiſſe your hand, and ſo leaue you: by this hand Clau-dio ſhall render me a deere account: as you heare of me, ſo thinke of me: goe comfort your coosin, I must ſay ſhe is dead, and ſo farewell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Constables, Borachio, and the Towne Clerke in gownes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeper.
SPEECH.LINE: Is our whole diſſembly appeard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowley.
SPEECH.LINE: O a ſtoole and a cushion for the Sexton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: Which be the malefactors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry that am I, and my partner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowley.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that’s certaine, wee haue the exhibition to examine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: But which are the offenders that are to be ex-amined, let them come before master Constable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea marry, let them come before mee, what is your name, friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Borachio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kem.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray write downe Borachio. Yours ſirra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a Gentleman ſir, and my name is Conrade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kee.
SPEECH.LINE: Write downe Master gentleman Conrade: mai-sters, doe you ſerue God: maisters, it is proued alreadie that you are little better than false knaues, and it will goe neere to be thought ſo ſhortly, how anſwer you for your ſelues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, we ſay we are none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: A maruellous witty fellow I aſſure you, but I will goe about with him: come you hither ſirra, a word in your eare ſir, I ſay to you, it is thought you are false knaues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I ſay to you, we are none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſtand aside, 'fore God they are both in a tale: haue you writ downe that they are none?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sext.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Constable, you goe not the way to ex-amine, you must call forth the watch that are their ac-cusers. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea marry, that’s the eftest way, let the watch come forth: masters, I charge you in the Princes name, accuse these men. Watch 1. This man ſaid ſir, that Don Iohn the Princes brother was a villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Write down, Prince Iohn a villaine: why this is flat periurie, to call a Princes brother villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bora.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Constable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray thee fellow peace, I do not like thy looke
I promise thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: What heard you him ſay else? Watch 2. Mary that he had receiued a thousand Du-kates of Don Iohn, for accusing the Lady Hero wrong-fully. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Flat Burglarie as euer was committed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea by th’ maſſe that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: What else fellow? Watch 1. And that Count Claudio did meane vpon his words, to disgrace Hero before the whole aſſembly, and not marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: O villaine! thou wilt be condemn’d into euer-lasting redemption for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: What else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: This is all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sexton.
SPEECH.LINE: And this is more masters then you can deny, Prince Iohn is this morning ſecretly ſtolne away: Hero was in this manner accus’d, in this very manner refus’d, and vpon the griefe of this ſodainely died: Master Con-stable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonato, I will goe before, and ſhew him their examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let them be opinion’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sex.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them be in the hands of Coxcombe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kem.
SPEECH.LINE: Gods my life, where's the Sexton? let him write downe the Princes Officer Coxcombe: come, binde them thou naughty varlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Couley.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, you are an aſſe, you are an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou not ſuspect my place? dost thou not ſuspect my yeeres? O that hee were heere to write mee downe an aſſe! but masters, remember that I am an aſſe: though it be not written down, yet forget not y I am an aſſe: No thou villaine, y art full of piety as ſhall be prou’d vpon thee by good witneſſe, I am a wise fellow, and which is more, an officer, and which is more, a houshoul-der, and which is more, as pretty a peece of flesh as any in Meſſina, and one that knowes the Law, goe to, & a rich fellow enough, goe to, and a fellow that hath had loſſes, and one that hath two gownes, and euery thing hand-some about him: bring him away: O that I had been writ downe an aſſe!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brother.
SPEECH.LINE: If you goe on thus, you will kill your ſelfe,
And ‘tis not wisedome thus to ſecond griefe,
Against your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee cease thy counsaile,
Which falls into mine eares as profitleſſe,
As water in a ſiue: giue not me counsaile,
Nor let no comfort delight mine eare,
But ſuch a one whose wrongs doth ſute with mine.
Bring me a father that ſo lou’d his childe,
Whose ioy of her is ouer-whelmed like mine,
And bid him ſpeake of patience,
Measure his wœ the length and bredth of mine,
And let it answere euery ſtraine for ſtraine,
As thus for thus, and ſuch a griefe for ſuch,
In euery lineament, branch, ſhape, and forme:
If ſuch a one will ſmile and ſtroke his beard,
And ſorrow, wagge, crie hem, when he ſhould grone,
Patch griefe with prouerbs, make misfortune drunke,
With candle-wasters: bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience:
But there is no ſuch man, for brother, men
Can counsaile, and ſpeake comfort to that griefe,
Which they themselues not feele, but tasting it,
Their counsaile turnes to paſſion, which before,
Would giue preceptiall medicine to rage,
Fetter ſtrong madneſſe in a ſilken thred,
Charme ache with ayre, and agony with words,
No, no, ‘tis all mens office, to ſpeake patience
To those that wring vnder the load of ſorrow:
But no mans vertue nor ſufficiencie
To be ſo morall, when he ſhall endure
The like himselfe: therefore giue me no counsaile,
My griefs cry lowder then aduertisement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broth.
SPEECH.LINE: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee peace, I will be flesh and bloud,
For there was neuer yet Philosopher,
That could endure the tooth-ake patiently,
How euer they haue writ the ſtile of gods,
And made a push at chance and ſufferance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brother.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet bend not all the harme vpon your ſelfe,
Make those that doe offend you, ſuffer too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: There thou ſpeak'st reason, nay I will doe ſo,
My ſoule doth tell me, Hero is belied,
And that ſhall Claudio know, ſo ſhall the Prince,
And all of them that thus dishonour her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brot.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good den, good den.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day to both of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare you my Lords?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue ſome haste Leonato.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Some haste my Lord! wel, fareyouwel my Lord,
Are you ſo hasty now? well, all is one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, do not quarrel with vs, good old man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brot.
SPEECH.LINE: If he could rite himselfe with quarrelling,
Some of vs would lie low.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Who wrongs him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry y dost wrong me, thou diſſembler, thou:
Nay, neuer lay thy hand vpon thy ſword,
I feare thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry beshrew my hand,
If it ſhould giue your age ſuch cause of feare,
Infaith my hand meant nothing to my ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Tuſh, tuſh, man, neuer fleere and iest at me,
I ſpeake not like a dotard, nor a foole,
As vnder priuiledge of age to bragge,
What I haue done being yong, or what would doe,
Were I not old, know Claudio to thy head,
Thou hast ſo wrong’d my innocent childe and me,
That I am forc’d to lay my reuerence by,
And with grey haires and bruise of many daies,
Doe challenge thee to triall of a man,
I ſay thou hast belied mine innocent childe.
Thy ſlander hath gone through and through her heart,
And ſhe lies buried with her ancestors:
O in a tombe where neuer ſcandall ſlept,
Saue this of hers, fram’d by thy villanie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: My villany?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SPEECH.LINE: Thine Claudio, thine I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay not right old man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, my Lord,
Ile proue it on his body if he dare,
Despight his nice fence, and his actiue practise,
His Maie of youth, and bloome of lustihood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, I will not haue to do with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Canst thou ſo daffe me? thou hast kild my child,
If thou kilst me, boy, thou ſhalt kill a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bro.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall kill two of vs, and men indeed,
But that’s no matter, let him kill one first:
Win me and weare me, let him answere me,
Come follow me boy, come ſir boy, come follow me
Sir boy, ile whip you from your foyning fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brot.
SPEECH.LINE: Content your ſelf, God knows I lou’d my neece,
And ſhe is dead, ſlander’d to death by villaines,
That dare as well anſwer a man indeede,
As I dare take a ſerpent by the tongue.
Boyes, apes, braggarts, Iackes, milke-sops.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother Anthony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brot.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold you content, what man? I know them, yea
And what they weigh, euen to the vtmost ſcruple,
Scambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boyes,
That lye, and cog, and flout, depraue, and ſlander,
Goe antiquely, and ſhow outward hidiousneſſe,
And ſpeake of halfe a dozen dang'rous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst.
And this is all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: But brother Anthonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, ‘tis no matter,
Do not you meddle, let me deale in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pri.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience
My heart is ſorry for your daughters death:
But on my honour ſhe was charg’d with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not heare you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: No come brother, away, I will be heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bro.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhall, or ſome of vs will ſmart for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: See, ſee, here comes the man we went to ſeeke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſignior, what newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome ſignior, you are almost come to part almost a fray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee had likt to haue had our two noses ſnapt off with two old men without teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Leonato and his brother, what think'st thou? had wee fought, I doubt we ſhould haue beene too yong for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: In a false quarrell there is no true valour, I came to ſeeke you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue beene vp and downe to ſeeke thee, for we are high proofe melancholly, and would faine haue it beaten away, wilt thou vse thy wit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: It is in my ſcabberd, ſhall I draw it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Doest thou weare thy wit by thy ſide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer any did ſo, though verie many haue been beside their wit, I will bid thee drawe, as we do the min-strels, draw to pleasure vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: As I am an honeſt man he lookes pale, art thou ſicke, or angrie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: What, courage man: what though care kil’d a cat, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I ſhall meete your wit in the careere, and you charge it against me, I pray you chuse another ſub-iect. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then giue him another ſtaffe, this last was broke croſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: By this light, he changes more and more, I thinke he be angrie indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be, he knowes how to turne his girdle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I ſpeake a word in your eare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe me from a challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a villaine, I iest not, I will make it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare: do me right, or I will protest your cowardise: you haue kill’d a ſweete Ladie, and her death ſhall fall heauie on you, let me heare from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will meete you, ſo I may haue good cheare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What, a feast, a feast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I faith I thanke him, he hath bid me to a calues head and a Capon, the which if I doe not carue mo’t cu-riously, ſay my knife's naught, ſhall I not finde a wood-cocke too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, your wit ambles well, it goes easily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell thee how Beatrice prais’d thy wit the o-ther day: I ſaid thou hadst a fine wit: true ſaies ſhe, a fine little one: no ſaid I, a great wit: right ſaies ſhee, a great groſſe one: nay ſaid I, a good wit: iust ſaid ſhe, it hurts no body: nay ſaid I, the gentleman is wise: certaine ſaid ſhe, a wise gentleman: nay ſaid I, he hath the tongues: that I beleeue ſaid ſhee, for hee ſwore a thing to me on munday night, which he forswore on tuesday morning: there's a double tongue, there's two tongues: thus did ſhee an howre together trans-shape thy particular ver-tues, yet at last ſhe concluded with a ſigh, thou wast the proprest man in Italie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: For the which ſhe wept heartily, and ſaid ſhee car’d not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea that ſhe did, but yet for all that, and if ſhee did not hate him deadlie, ſhee would loue him dearely, the old mans daughter told vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: All, all, and moreouer, God ſaw him when he was hid in the garden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: But when ſhall we ſet the ſauage Bulls hornes on the ſensible Benedicks head?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea and text vnder-neath, heere dwells Bene-dicke the married man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well, Boy, you know my minde, I will leaue you now to your goſſep-like humor, you breake iests as braggards do their blades, which God be thank-ed hurt not: my Lord, for your manie courtesies I thank you, I must discontinue your companie, your brother the Bastard is fled from Meſſina: you haue among you, kill’d a ſweet and innocent Ladie: for my Lord Lacke-beard there, he and I ſhall meete, and till then peace be with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: He is in earnest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: In mo’t profound earnest, and Ile warrant you, for the loue of Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: And hath challeng’d thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſincerely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What a prettie thing man is, when he goes in his doublet and hose, and leaues off his wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: He is then a Giant to an Ape, but then is an Ape a Doctor to ſuch a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſoft you, let me be, plucke vp my heart, and be ſad, did he not ſay my brother was fled?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Come you ſir, if iustice cannot tame you, ſhee ſhall nere weigh more reasons in her ballance, nay, and you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be lookt to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, two of my brothers men bound? Bo-rachio one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Harken after their offence my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Officers, what offence haue these men done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir, they haue committed false report, moreouer they haue ſpoken vntruths, ſecondarily they are ſlanders, ſixt and lastly, they haue belyed a Ladie, thirdly, they haue verified vniust things, and to conclude they are lying knaues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: First I aske thee what they haue done, thirdlie I aske thee what’s their offence, ſixt and lastlie why they are committed, and to conclude, what you lay to their charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Rightlie reasoned, and in his owne diuision, and by my troth there's one meaning well ſuted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Who haue you offended masters, that you are thus bound to your anſwer? this learned Constable is too cunning to be vnderstood, what’s your offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete Prince, let me go no farther to mine an-swere: do you heare me, and let this Count kill mee: I haue deceiued euen your verie eies: what your wise-domes could not discouer, these ſhallow fooles haue brought to light, who in the night ouerheard me con-feſſing to this man, how Don Iohn your brother incensed me to ſlander the Ladie Hero, how you were brought into the Orchard, and ſaw me court Margaret in Herœs garments, how you disgrac’d her when you ſhould marrie her: my villanie they haue vpon record, which I had rather ſeale with my death, then repeate ouer to my ſhame: the Ladie is dead vpon mine and my masters false accusation: and briefelie, I desire nothing but the reward of a villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Runs not this ſpeech like yron through your bloud?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue drunke poison whiles he vtter’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: But did my Brother ſet thee on to this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: He is compos’d and fram’d of treacherie,
And fled he is vpon this villanie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appeare
In the rare ſemblance that I lou’d it first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, bring away the plaintiffes, by this time our Sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter: and masters, do not forget to ſpecifie when time & place ſhall ſerue, that I am an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.2.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the villaine? let me ſee his eies,
That when I note another man like him,
I may auoide him: which of these is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: If you would know your wronger, looke on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou the ſlaue that with thy breath hast kild mine innocent childe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, euen I alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not ſo villaine, thou beliest thy ſelfe,
Here ſtand a paire of honourable men,
A third is fled that had a hand in it:
I thanke you Princes for my daughters death,
Record it with your high and worthie deedes,
'Twas brauely done, if you bethinke you of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must ſpeake, choose your reuenge your ſelfe,
Impose me to what penance your inuention
Can lay vpon my ſinne, yet ſinn’d I not,
But in mistaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: By my ſoule nor I,
And yet to ſatisfie this good old man,
I would bend vnder anie heauie waight,
That heele enioyne me to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot bid you bid my daughter liue,
That were impoſſible, but I praie you both,
Poſſeſſe the people in Meſſina here,
How innocent ſhe died, and if your loue
Can labour aught in ſad inuention,
Hang her an epitaph vpon her toomb,
And ſing it to her bones, ſing it to night:
To morrow morning come you to my house,
And ſince you could not be my ſonne in law,
Be yet my Nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copie of my childe that’s dead,
And ſhe alone is heire to both of vs,
Giue her the right you ſhould haue giu'n her cosin,
And ſo dies my reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: O noble ſir!
Your ouerkindneſſe doth wring teares from me,
I do embrace your offer, and dispose
For henceforth of poore Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow then I will expect your comming,
To night I take my leaue, this naughtie man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I beleeue was packt in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bor.
SPEECH.LINE: No, by my ſoule ſhe was not,
Nor knew not what ſhe did when ſhe ſpoke to me,
But alwaies hath bin iust and vertuous,
In anie thing that I do know by her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Moreouer ſir, which indeede is not vnder white and black, this plaintiffe here, the offendour did call mee aſſe, I beseech you let it be remembred in his punish-ment, and also the watch heard them talke of one Defor-med, they ſay he weares a key in his eare and a lock hang-ing by it, and borrowes monie in Gods name, the which he hath vs’d ſo long, and neuer paied, that now men grow hard-harted and will lend nothing for Gods ſake: praie you examine him vpon that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee for thy care and honeſt paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship ſpeakes like a mo’t thankefull and reuerend youth, and I praise God for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: There's for thy paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue the foundation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thanke thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: I leaue an arrant knaue with your worship, which I beseech your worship to correct your ſelfe, for the example of others: God keepe your worship, I wish your worship well, God restore you to health, I humblie giue you leaue to depart, and if a mer-rie meeting may be wisht, God prohibite it: come neighbour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Vntill to morrow morning, Lords, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brot.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell my Lords, we looke for you to mor-row.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: We will not faile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: To night ile mourne with Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring you these fellowes on, weel talke with Margaret, How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Praie thee ſweete Mistris Margaret, deserue well at my hands, by helping mee to the ſpeech of Bea-trice. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you then write me a Sonnet in praise of my beautie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſo high a ſtile Margaret, that no man liuing ſhall come ouer it, for in mo’t comely truth thou deser-uest it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue no man come ouer me, why, ſhall I al-waies keepe below ſtaires?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy wit is as quicke as the grey-hounds mouth, it catches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: And yours, as blunt as the Fencers foiles, which hit, but hurt not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t manly wit Margaret, it will not hurt a woman: and ſo I pray thee call Beatrice, I giue thee the bucklers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue vs the ſwords, wee haue bucklers of our owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: If you vse them Margaret, you must put in the pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for Maides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I thinke hath legges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: And therefore will come. The God of loue that ſits aboue, and knowes me, and knowes me, how pitti-full I deserue. I meane in ſinging, but in louing, Lean-der the good ſwimmer, Troilous the first imploier of pandars, and a whole booke full of these quondam car-pet-mongers, whose name yet runne ſmoothly in the e-uen rode of a blanke verse, why they were neuer ſo true-ly turned ouer and ouer as my poore ſelfe in loue: mar-rie I cannot ſhew it rime, I haue tried, I can finde out no rime to Ladie but babie, an innocent rime: for ſcorne, horne, a hard rime: for ſchoole foole, a babling rime: verie ominous endings, no, I was not borne vnder a ri-ming Plannet, for I cannot woœ in festiuall tearmes: Enter Beatrice. ſweete Beatrice would'st thou come when I cal’d thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea Signior, and depart when you bid me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſtay but till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Then, is ſpoken: fare you well now, and yet ere I goe, let me goe with that I came, which is, with know-ing what hath past betweene you and Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely foule words, and thereupon I will kiſſe thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Foule words is but foule wind, and foule wind is but foule breath, and foule breath is noisome, there-fore I will depart vnkist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right ſence, ſo forcible is thy wit, but I must tell thee plainely, Claudio vndergœs my challenge, and either I must ſhort-ly heare from him, or I will ſubscribe him a coward, and I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in loue with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: For them all together, which maintain’d ſo politique a ſtate of euill, that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them: but for which of my good parts did you first ſuffer loue for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Suffer loue! a good epithite, I do ſuffer loue in-deede, for I loue thee against my will,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſpight of your heart I think, alas poore heart, if you ſpight it for my ſake, I will ſpight it for yours, for I will neuer loue that which my friend hates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou and I are too wise to woœ peacea-blie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bea.
SPEECH.LINE: It appeares not in this confeſſion, there's not one wise man among twentie that will praise himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: An old, an old instance Beatrice, that liu’d in the time of good neighbours, if a man doe not erect in this age his owne tombe ere he dies, hee ſhall liue no longer in monuments, then the Bels ring, & the Widdow weepes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: And how long is that thinke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Question, why an hower in clamour and a quar-ter in rhewme, therfore is it mo’t expedient for the wise, if Don worme (his conscience) finde no impediment to the contrarie, to be the trumpet of his owne vertues, as I am to my ſelfe ſo much for praising my ſelfe, who I my ſelfe will beare witneſſe is praise worthie, and now tell me, how doth your cosin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: And how doe you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie ill too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Serue God, loue me, and mend, there will I leaue you too, for here comes one in haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vrs.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, you must come to your Vncle, yon-ders old coile at home, it is prooued my Ladie He-ro hath bin falselie accusde, the Prince and Claudio mightilie abusde, and Don Iohn is the author of all, who is fled and gone: will you come presentlie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you go heare this newes Signior?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: I will liue in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be bu-ried in thy eies: and moreouer, I will goe with thee to thy Vncles.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or foure with Tapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the monument of Leonato?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord
SPEECH.LINE: It is my Lord. Epitaph.
Done to death by ſlanderous tongues,
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death in guerdon of her wrongs,
Giues her fame which neuer dies:
So the life that dyed with ſhame,
Liues in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there vpon the tombe,
Praising her when I am dombe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Now musick ſound & ſing your ſolemn hymne
Pardon goddeſſe of the night,
Those that ſlew thy virgin knight,
For the which with ſongs of wœ,
Round about her tombe they goe:
Midnight aſſist our mone, helpe vs to ſigh and grone.
Heauily, heauily.
Graues yawne and yeelde your dead,
Till death be vttered,
Heauenly, heauenly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.
SPEECH.LINE: Now vnto thy bones good night, yeerely will I do this right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow masters, put your Torches out,
The wolues haue preied, and looke, the gentle day
Before the wheeles of Phœbus, round about
Dapples the drowsie East with ſpots of grey:
Thanks to you all, and leaue vs, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow masters, each his ſeuerall way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come let vs hence, and put on other weedes,
And then to Leonatœs we will goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And Hymen now with luckier iſſue ſpeeds,
Then this for whom we rendred vp this wœ.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Leonato, Bene. Marg. Vrsula, old man, Frier, Hero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: Did I not tell you ſhe was innocent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: So are the Prince and Claudio who accus’d her,
Vpon the errour that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in ſome fault for this,
Although against her will as it appeares,
In the true course of all the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I am glad that all things ſort ſo well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I, being else by faith enforc’d
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by your ſelues,
And when I ſend for you, come hither mask’d:
The Prince and Claudio promis’d by this howre
To visit me, you know your office Brother,
You must be father to your brothers daughter,
And giue her to young Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: Which I will doe with confirm’d countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Frier, I must intreat your paines, I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: To doe what Signior?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: To binde me, or vndœ me, one of them:
Signior Leonato, truth it is good Signior,
Your neece regards me with an eye of fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: That eye my daughter lent her, ‘tis mo’t true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: And I doe with an eye of loue requite her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſight whereof I thinke you had from me,
From Claudio, and the Prince, but what’s your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bened.
SPEECH.LINE: Your anſwer ſir is Enigmaticall,
But for my will, my will is, your good will
May ſtand with ours, this day to be conioyn’d,
In the ſtate of honourable marriage,
In which (good Frier) I ſhall desire your helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: My heart is with your liking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: And my helpe.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince and Claudio, with attendants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow to this faire aſſembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Prince, good morrow Claudio:
We heere attend you, are you yet determin’d,
To day to marry with my brothers daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile hold my minde were ſhe an Ethiope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: Call her forth brother, heres the Frier ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Benedicke, why what’s the matter?
That you haue ſuch a Februarie face,
So full of frost, of ſtorme, and clowdineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Claud.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke he thinkes vpon the ſauage bull:
Tuſh, feare not man, wee'll tip thy hornes with gold,
And all Europa ſhall reioyce at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Ioue,
When he would play the noble beast in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Bull Ioue ſir, had an amiable low,
And ſome ſuch ſtrange bull leapt your fathers Cow,
A got a Calfe in that ſame noble feat,
Much like to you, for you haue iust his bleat.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Vrsula.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: For this I owe you: here comes other recknings.
Which is the Lady I must ſeize vpon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leo.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſame is ſhe, and I doe giue you her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then ſhe's mine, ſweet let me ſee your face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: No that you ſhal not, till you take her hand,
Before this Frier, and ſweare to marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand before this holy Frier,
I am your husband if you like of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: And when I liu’d I was your other wife,
And when you lou’d, you were my other husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Another Hero?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died, but I doe liue,
And ſurely as I liue, I am a maid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: The former Hero, Hero that is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee died my Lord, but whiles her ſlander liu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Frier.
SPEECH.LINE: All this amazement can I qualifie,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
Ile tell you largely of faire Herœs death:
Meane time let wonder ſeeme familiar,
And to the chappell let vs presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ben.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft and faire Frier, which is Beatrice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I anſwer to that name, what is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not you loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no, no more then reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your Vncle, and the Prince, & Clau-dio, haue beene deceiued, they ſwore you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not you loue mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth no, no more then reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then my Cosin Margaret and Vrsula
Are much deceiu’d, for they did ſweare you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſwore you were almost ſicke for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſwore you were wel-nye dead for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis no matter, then you doe not loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: No truly, but in friendly recompence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Cosin, I am ſure you loue the gentlema[n].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: And Ile be ſworne vpon't, that he loues her,
For heres a paper written in his hand,
A halting ſonnet of his owne pure braine,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hero.
SPEECH.LINE: And heeres another,
Writ in my cosins hand, ſtolne from her pocket,
Containing her affection vnto Benedicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: A miracle, here's our owne hands against our hearts: come I will haue thee, but by this light I take thee for pittie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beat.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not denie you, but by this good day, I yeeld vpon great perswasion, & partly to ſaue your life, for I was told, you were in a consumption.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace I will ſtop your mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How dost thou Benedicke the married man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell thee what Prince: a Colledge of witte-crackers cannot flout mee out of my humour, dost thou think I care for a Satyre or an Epigram? no, if a man will be beaten with braines, a ſhall weare nothing handsome about him: in briefe, ſince I do purpose to marry, I will thinke nothing to any purpose that the world can ſay a-gainst it, and therefore neuer flout at me, for I haue ſaid against it: for man is a giddy thing, and this is my con-clusion: for thy part Claudio, I did thinke to haue beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman, liue vn-bruis’d, and loue my cousin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: I had well hop’d y wouldst haue denied Beatrice, y I might haue cudgel’d thee out of thy ſingle life, to make thee a double dealer, which out of questio[n] thou wilt be, if my Cousin do not looke exceeding narrowly to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, we are friends, let's haue a dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts, and our wiues heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Leon.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'll haue dancing afterward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: First, of my word, therfore play musick. Prince, thou art ſad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife, there is no ſtaff more reuerend then one tipt with horn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſen.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, your brother Iohn is tane in flight,
And brought with armed men backe to Meſſina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bene.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke not on him till to morrow, ile deuise thee braue punishments for him: ſtrike vp Pipers.
